reviewText:
Slain Expectations

Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

And so like The Lady before it, Steam has sharted out another half-baked indie title for us to enjoy in the waning days of winter – this time it's Slain!, an arcadey, 2D hack n' slash. Let me get this out of the way right off the bat: this isn't an AWFUL game. It looks great... no, it looks SPECTACULAR. This is lovingly crafted stuff: the baddies, the bosses, the backgrounds, the foregrounds, the GROUNDgrounds! It's a slick looking, heavy metal album cover of a game.

But it all falls apart, unfortunately, like a conversation with a beautiful airhead.

“So what kind of hobbies do you have, Slain!?”

“Pizza!”

“Pizza isn't a hobby, Slain.”

“Horses!”

“Alright, we're done here.”

It's just kind of... vapid? That's my biggest complaint, and the most damning, unpatchable one. The combat has no impact... and that's CRITICAL for a hack n' slash. What it lacks in combat depth it should make up for in VIOLENT, RADICAL, FEEL-GOOD COMBAT. It doesn't sound good, and it doesn't feel good. The majority of the game you can spam the attack button and watch as the minions of SATAN crumble like so much tissue paper before your standard sword.  Hell, I didn't realize I could switch between elemental weapons or use spirit bombs until halfway through the game (I figured they mentioned fire, ice, and steel as a Game of Thrones reference or something, honestly). I guess that's another issue in and of itself: the game doesn't really explain itself well. “Spirit bombs are great for clearing out tons of enemies!” Thanks game! How in the ♥♥♥♥ do I do that?

And besides all that you run along a fairly linear path, slapping switches and jumping on platforms. It's all very uninspired, save for the brilliant art design. And the story? Forgettable. You play as one Geralt - I mean Bathoryn? And you have been brought back to life to destroy evil? And that's that. Go around and kill evil. And the dialogue is bizarrely disjointed - sometimes they stick to the old timey spiel, sometimes there's a weird modern tone that's just short of LOL."

This is likely a byproduct of this game having been rushed out the door before it was ready... it was delayed at least twice as far as I know

reviewText:
Slain! is unfortunately the embodyment of a game that looks great in still images but sadly falls apart upon being played. I was looking forward to it for ages but there's just so many problems that they overpower the great atmosphere and badass world the developers have created.

The general gist is that Slain! comes across a bit like Volgarr The Viking with an old school 'hack and slash' approach set in a beautifully realized metal album cover full of blood and gore and demons of all types. The pixel art is incredible in the vast majority of the game and I can't stress enough how talented the artist is. Sadly I experienced a lot of negatives in my time with Slain. Rather sluggish & stiff controls, repetitive combat (usually you can break enemy AI or mash), iffy collision boxes, difficult to read text/story typeface, confusing and arbitrary level design, music that loops too frequently, frustrating trial & error segments, imbalanced checkpoint placement, janky animations, lack of auditory and visual feedback, audio bugs and barely functioning menus... the list goes on. The game honestly needed a bunch more work and polish before release.

I do appreciate what the developers were going for with Slain! and I believe the concept has a ton of potential, but it just wasn't where it needed to be by launch. I sincerely hope they'll keep addressing the issues after they get more feedback and I'll be happy to change my stance (and review) if that takes place. For now though, I think it may be better to wait on this one.

reviewText:
Early Kickstarter backer and shower-offer-to-friends-er, with rather hurt feelings about it all

During development, update-after-update showed new sprites or boasted new music but rarely if ever info on combat, gameplay, enemy AI.

That fact says it all.

Cringing from the writing (which is so bad it seems like an active attempt to *sabotage* the game), even before I got to experience the extremely painful controls and terrible combat.

Music is really cool for a few minutes but 30 mins in, it was getting very very repetitive.

== And the long rant version of this review: ==

The controls are fundamentally painful. You have to hold a button down for about a second just to turn around, due to mistakenly implemented analog sensitivity in Unity even when using a keyboard. Attack combos are an inconsistent mish-mash. I think that duck is the same as block but you're better off trying to bash the attack button since blocking only works on projectiles--meaning if fighting melee & ranged opponents simultaneously, blocking gets you killed.

After pressing every key on my keyboard I found a cool looking fireball which was semi-useful.

Earn mana by using 'decapitate' button (W key--you're welcome) but it only works on enemies with very low HP, and it's slow and short-ranged and leaves you vulnerable. It seems to me to be essentially useless since you can't gauge enemy HP (unless you count the hits you've made and know how many it takes, but that's nearly impossible when fihgting 2-3 at once). Even if one of the enemies in a group is low enough, using decap means you'll almost certainly be hit 1-2x by the other guys.

Attempting to hit an enemy and then run or run and turn around and attack again is entirely futile, due to the terrible turn-around speed and very very clunky controls. The dodge key itself didn't prove useful enough to bother with due to the clunkiness (approach enemy, attack, dodge--you're likely to be hit before your attack finishes and the dodge executes).

Fortunately, I was able to dispatch groups of enemies by simply standing on a raised ledge, watching them walk endlessly into it, and attacking them whilst crouching. Take that, mindless undead!

My general feeling about the combat was that MAYBE it would be possible to game it perfectly and get past enemies by maintaining a specific distance, attacking, dodging backward, attacking again but I'm no slouch and after many many lives lost, found it nearly impossible to defeat groups without sustaining damage.

I got so frustrated by the controls after what what was probably my 20th attempt at getting past a section leading up to the red skelly" right after entering the 1st temple that I closed the game so can't comment any further.

I'll try to check back after some patches have been released in a month or two

Although I had no problem whatsoever with the controls, I still hated the  game. And here's why:

First, let's talk about what I loved about it. The art style. The graphics. The visuals... That's about it.

There are two reasons I hated it, and a couple of nitpicks. First, the sound design is kinda messed up. Things that should to be loud are not, and things that should not be loud, are really loud. I don't know how to explain it. When you play it, the lack of any grunts from the character or enemies seems really weird in a game like this. And the music is either too loud or not loud enough, depending on what setting you put it on. There is no middle ground. And speaking of the music, it was a big let down. At first, it sounds awesome. But then it gets really repetitive real fast. To make my point easier, pretend that you are listening to a Behemoth song with no vocals and no solos... for like 15 minutes... It isn't as good as you would expect.

The second reason I hated it is the bigger one, which is the combat. Look, for a 2D action game like this, you should either have a 1 or 2 attack style like Castlevania or Rogue Legacy, in which you hit with 1 weapon and 1 move, but you have another attack like throwing knives or something. Or you have the second kind which is fluid combos like Dust: An Elysian Tale or Salt And Sanctuary. You can perform multiple combos with easy to handle timed button presses. This game has neither. Your weapon is too weak and too stiff to use like Castlevania's whip, and your character isn't fast enough to pull it off. And the combo system in the game is just too bad. It needs lightning speed reflexes to pull off a 3 hit combo which isn't even that good. I found that none of my hits give knockback to the enemies. And the fact that you have to be right in front of their pixalated face to be able to hit them means you will be taking a lot of damage as well. The only way I was able to progress without getting much damage is crouching and spamming the hit button, because that attack is the only attack that gives some sort of knockback effect on the enemy... Almost.

Overall, the game is a complete mess, and I was really sad about that. I was so looking forward to it, and it hurts me to see it in such an unplayable mess. I do hope they fix it, but I doubt they will. I'll give it a week... Then I'm gonna refund it if it is still unfinished.

reviewText:
Target Audience:    Those who are Masochist in nature, and want a visual and audio experience more then anything else.

Video Review:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=madiTJFmJy0

Summary:
A lot of flash, but not a lot to back it up. A lot of the major problems that Slain has to do with basic game and level design: there's some basic problems regarding the different gameplay parts working together in harmony: which is a major problem. The level design can be nasty at times, relying on trial and error more then environment recognition or skill. Now it's not that hard in terms of difficulty: the game relies on exploiting the AI and using pattern recognition to not taking damage. And at first, that works. But it's the lack of enemy variety in combination of repeating the levels over and over again that makes the experience hard to drag through. It's not the scourge of the earth as some other reviews have said, but the game frustrated me from the get go, and continued to do it without offering something that great in return. It doesn't help that the engine lacks precision, as not only will enemies can hit you in death animations, but the game will spawn enemies on top of you regardless of fairness or not. And don't get me started on a PC game launched with this kind of keyboard support, it's one of the worst I've seen, and that's for a game that was delayed SEVERAL times. It's a shame, I was really looking forward to the game, and it just couldn't deliver in the end.

Lists:
Positives:
Aesthetic. A strong artstyle along with some great music. You haven't really seen a game like this.
Slow methodical gameplay that relies on memorization and pattern recognition. Has an original castlevania element to it: find the way to exploit the AI to avoid damage and dying.
The different elemental weapons does add some variety to the gameplay due to enemy weaknesses and weapon range.
Good alternative wolf section that varied the gameplay up.
The game works well for the gameplay in question for the controller. It takes time to get used to, but it's more about slow and steady gameplay more then anything else.
Those who are able to pick up on small environmental hints will do well in this game. A sharp eye is almost required without relying on trial and error gameplay.
Negatives:
Keyboard controls are horrible. The game should not have launched in this state with it being a PC port, or at least have required the use of a controller. Inexcusable.
Trial and Error gameplay. This can be seen on multiple levels: but for example: the game will spawn enemies right on top of you, and if it's the first time you've been in an area, you're in for a nasty shock as you have no time to react. You only learn where they spawn, then can deal with it.
Lack of precision on the engine at times, as you can be hit by dead enemies.
Level Design is very poor at times, leading to unavoidable traps and nasty situations that ask too much of the player.

I really wanted to like and recommend this game. The art looks excellent, animations look fluid, the sound is ok too, I myself had been keeping an eye on this game for a while which makes writing this review kind of sad.

So, this is a very early review because I feel like some of the early negative reviews are not fully thought out. I will try to keep it simple.

I:
I have no issues with controller lag. I use an Xbox 360 controller to play, I do get a second or so of lag with the keyboard (left and right direction only) so this must be a keyboard issue only, for now. I was about to see what they meant after I got the first sword powerupgrade to realize that these specific enemies, not going spoil anything, are better to fight without the powerupgrade. Sword powers are interchangeable or can be turned off. This adds a little tactic and strategy, which is a positive in my eyes. Also, people might be trying to play this game on to high of a setting for their computer, which unsurprisingly could cause input lag and FPS drops.

IMPORTANT NOTE Before playing the game you get a box that lets you choose graphic display such as resolution, quality, window or fullscreen, and Display 1 (2,3, etc.). The same box also shows you the controller and keyboard setup, which you can reassign the keys (Only movement keys can be reassigned). So, knowing which keyboard keys to press can be a mystery. Seems that QWER (attack), 1234...(Mana attack/swordupgrade), P (pause) and ENTER are used but I haven't played much with the keyboard controls.

II:
Sound, yes the soundtrack is great. However, I agree it is a little loud. So what I did was go into options and turned it down a notch and guess what?! it made sound way better and I now hear all the little game sounds as well (e.g. foot steps, swinging sword, etc.). I also have good headphones so that might help. Also, if the soundtrack bores you than change how you play and try to get past that specific area instead of getting slain or mute it until you get past that area you keep having to repeat. PS the slain death screen is great.

III:
I have read discussion forums that GOG had an earlier build on release date and most people seem to be writing reviews off of that wrong release or not realizing everything offered to them; Or, some other technical issue that I seem not to have.

IV:
You can exit the screen withOUT Alt+Tab, no idea why someone said that only Alt+Tab will let you exit.

V:
Some letters in the game are hard to read due to the font choice, but logical guessing from storyline and other words I can make out what is being stated.

VI:
The pixel art is beautiful and I cannot wait to see what other enemies await as so far there has been a good mix.

VII:
Variety in attacks, including mana and weapon upgrades seem adequate and rather more than I expected them to include. I expected something closer to Castlevania but get a lot more and I am talking about NES castlevania style/types of weapon and attack choices.

VIII:
Yes you will be Slain! as the name implies and you know, I am okay with that. The popular Dark Souls is constant death as well as many other games, including this one, and for many this may be a new thing, but I think a good thing. Prepare to be Slain! is a no joke saying with this game.

I am enjoying this game and I do hope others see this review after reading the negative reviews. I would recommend this game to my friends and even bought a copy for a friend that also loves this genre.

I definitely will have more than .3 hrs after this review as long as my non-gaming life allows and if it really goes to pooper later in the game I will update my review. But so far it is what I expected plus more!

reviewText:
Slain! was a game that I had been waiting for and looking forward to enjoy for quite some time now, but unfortunately there's too not much I find enjoyable here.

The one good factor this game has going for it is the art design. Lots of great colours splashed about gothic-medieval architecture paint this game wonderfully. This game is wonderfully bright and dankly dark at the same time, and that is shown well with the levels of scrolling seen between the foreground, midground and background.

Sadly, the art is the only thing I find great at this time. The controls, in which I'm playing with an Xbox One controller, are clunky. It's as if the developers grew up, like myself, playing Castlevania. Now, I love Castlevania. I will gladly play some hardcore Castlevania or Super Castlevania and then cross the bridge right into some Symphony of The Night or Aria of Sorrow. However, that's what this game's gameplay feels like to me: that bridge.

The developers seem to have created their own bridge, but it's a little rickety. Slain! is a cross between the old school Castlevania and Symphony of the Night, but unfortnately they didn't find the right balance between the two. In Castlevania, the devs understood that enemies needed a wind up and to be kept at a length, hence the whip or the long arc for the sword. Slain! gave me a fat sword that doesn't really seem like this amazing warrior would use (except to butter his toast) because the range is laughably short and he swings it like I have to tell him how.

And he can't block unless he crouches.

I assume maybe there will be longer, better weapons in the game, but at this point, with the game telling me nothing about how to play the game, ie. crouching makes you block and the B button is for decapitations, I don't exactly care to play that far into it. The mixture of slow, unresponsive controls and sludge metal is not a good mix. I enjoy grindy metal at times, but when your game feels like a gelatinous cube, and it's okay to have a game feel that slow, it may be best to tuck away the sludge metal for later.

In some way I want to recommend this game, because it looks gorgeous and maybe with a fix to the responsiveness it could be a lot of fun, but I can't do it. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game. The problems with Slain! bum me out as I was so very much looking forward to an ultra-dark heavy metal kind of vibe in a video game, but this is a whoops.

reviewText:
I hate to have to leave a negative review for this game, it had so much potential. The last thing I want is to discourage the developers, because their heart was in the right place here, it just didn't work this time.

First and foremost, the controls are beyond clunky, and not in a charming Castlevania 1-3 way, where it's an art to adjust to the slow pace and deadly jump mechanics. but this is more like you're never sure if what you're trying to do is actually going to happen when you press the button. It just makes the game really frustrating to play, especially when you get lucky and make a lot of progress only to have the unresponsiveness and poor hit detection fail you at the worst time, and then have to start all over again. Also, it's kind of strange to be thrown into the game and have no idea what the controls are. I understand it's a relatively simple game, and I appreciate being spared an annoying unnecessary tutorial, but at least an option to view the controls in the options menu would have been nice. For example, there is text early in the game telling you to block projectiles...but no mention as to how to do so. If you're going to break the fourth wall by giving the player text instructions on the screen, you might as well go all the way and tell them how to do it, otherwise it's pointless. Of course I WANT to block the projectiles, I don't need to be told that. I only found out by accident about 20 minutes later that crouching is apparently a block, at least I think so. I managed to block about 50% of the projectiles by crouching. Also, when you go to quit the game, the character jumps upon selecting Quit from the pause menu. Not a big deal, doesn't take away from the experience, but just seems like another weird control thing that makes the game seem rushed and unfinished.

In addition to the control issues, I felt like the overall gameplay was very one-dimensional. You have 2 melee attacks, but the longer attack seems completely useless. There is nearly a full second pause after the attack ends where you are left vulnerable. No matter how I tried to use it, or how quickly I backdashed away from the enemy after, the...I guess we'll call it the red attack, led to me taking damage 100% of the time, and doesn't seem to do any more damage to the enemy than the basic attack. Or at least, not enough to justify taking damage yourself in exchange every time you use it. The level design was also kind of generic and unexciting. Not visually so, but the layout was predictable and didn't keep me interested, mostly just a direct line from left to right, jumping a few gaps along the way. The monsters were fine, decent enough variety early on, but without much audible feedback when fighting them, they also got tired quickly.

On that note, the sound is another major issue. The music is ok, but a bit more repetitive than expected, which gets old very quickly when you're stuck trying to trudge through one area for a long period of time hearing the same 2 power chords chugging for 15 minutes. As for the sound effects, they are barely there at all. By default, both music and sfx are set to 10 volume. After a few minutes, I turned the music down to 9, then 8, then 7, and kept turning my speaker volume up just to be able to hear the sound fx at all, but they are rather bland and generic sounding, which is a buzzkill. Sound is a big deal in a game like this. You want that big violent explosion of sound every time you kill something. Not to keep comparing to Castlevania, but in Symphony of the Night for example, every one of the 100+ monsters in that game had a unique death sound that was percussive with some burning noises and occasionally some howling/screaming that matched up perfectly with the dying animation...it makes the kills incredibly satisfying, and pulls you into the world. SotN wouldn't be nearly as legendary without the incredible sound design. Not that I held this to the same standard, obviously a very different situation, but in Slain, the only thing you hear is some soft clinking metal sounds and whooshing. It really cheapens the whole experience.

In spite of the poor gameplay and sound, I do have to say the game looks amazing. This is some of the best pixel art I've seen in recent memory. Everything about the game is visually beautiful, and before playing it, I thought even if the game wasn't stellar, it would be a pleasure to play just for the visuals, but unfortunately that wasn't the case. I wish I could have enjoyed more of the scenery, but after about an hour, I'd had enough.

I appreciate the effort that went into this, and I can tell what the intent of the game was, but it has too many problems to be enjoyable in this state. It just feels incomplete. If I had played this as an early access title, I could give a pass to a lot of these problems while the bugs are still being worked out, but it was sold as a complete game, and it really could have used a little more time in the oven.

reviewText:
Slain! is a 2D action platformer, releasing on Steam on March 24th 2016, being developed by Wolf Brew Games. Players will control Bathoyrn, a hero in the gothic world, seeing to liberate seven great towers from 7 deadly overlords.

Gameplay is played from a side view, and you have to hack and slash your way through levels, using heavy attacks, quick attacks or magical spells. A lot of the negative reviews on Steam are pointing out that the game has poor unresponsive controls. Whilst this is true in some points, I feel like it is not as big of an issue that people are making out. Not to mention the developers have already acknowledges the issues and are working on a patch to be released.  The platforming elements in Slain are few and far between, there is a number of jumping puzzles, but none that have you re-doing the stage over and over again because you miss a ledge, each of the jumping puzzles are concluded within a minute or two leaving it a stress-free challenge. I would of liked to have seen a little more in-depth combat mechanics in game, and maybe even some sort of talent tree/unlock system through levelling up to add some additional abilities, but alas.

Visually, Slain is absolutely gorgeous. The pixel graphic style hits all of the right notes and it is easily one of, if not the best pixel style game I have ever seen. The backgrounds of all of the levels are stunning and perfectly hit the mood of the game on the head. The character models of the player and enemies are all very high quality as well. The attack cycles of all of the characters animation are fluid and look amazing to see playout. The graphical department is definitely Slain!’s strongest point.

Slain! is hard, a lot of timing has go into when to strike your enemy, trying to remember attack patterns of your foes will also make the combat easier to overcome too. Thankfully each level has a number of checkpoints evenly spread out across the stage meaning if you do die, you don’t have to replay the whole stage again.

Now, I am not 100% sure whether I have finished the game to be completely honest. I got an ending cut scene, or so it felt like it, with a “To be continued” at the end, but looking at the achievements, I haven’t got any apart from one. I definitely haven’t defeated a giant spider; I haven’t defeated the “Mega Beholder”, Horge, or Lord Vroll. I am not sure how I fight these, and I am not sure how I go about seeing the rest of the content; is it even present in the game? I’m not sure.  For what I have played so far, and if it is the game I have finished, it only took me just under two hours. That for me is a little on the short side. Like I said, this could be a bug, with the game; I am just not sure and would welcome a response from a dev on the point.

Technically, the game is OK. I will mimic the concerns about the controller issues that people are having in that they aren’t hugely responsive at times.  Some sort of tutorial system would be welcome too, rather than being chucked into the game and being expected to know what all of the buttons do right off the bat. Slain also has an issue at points where invisible walls prevented me from progressing through the stage, when it is quite clearly the way I needed to progress - this only happened when I was trying to jump over traps though.  I was happily surprised I could play the game on 4k resolutions though which for me is a nice addition.

Slain is a game that I was extremely hyped over for a number of months. I was disappointed when the game was delayed a few weeks ago, and couldn’t wait to pick it up on launch this past week. Maybe I was a little too hyped for it because I expected a lot from it. In the game’s current state I can simply recommend it for action/platformer fans as it is an interested take on the genre, hopefully the developers can clear up the technical issues and shed some light on the content that I seem to have missed. The price tag of £8,99 may be a bit too high at the moment for only 2 hours’ worth of content, so this is one to watch out for when on sale.

reviewText:
I had pretty high expectations for this game, and like many others, followed it for a while. What we got was a huge disappointment. I played some of it outside of Steam for a bit to ensure I'd have the refund option available if I chose to do so.
First and foremost, the art style is beautiful. If there's one thing that this game does get right, it's the graphics (for the most part.) However, aesthetics alone aren't enough to hold this together.
The controls are fairly clunky and unresponsive; for a platformer, controls need to be tight. Which they aren't.
Combat could use some help. You string together the same three-hit combo- which is fine, though the window to actiate the next attack is odd. I can't tell if the button is supposed to be pressed immediately, if there's supposed to be a delay, or what because the devs didn't exactly provide any kind of instructions on controls whatsoever. It's also hard to attack monsters at such close range without them hitting you back. But with a game that's supposed to be about butchering a bunch of monsters, attacking like an opportunist coward seems a little disappointing. There's also no cue, visual or audio, that you've been hit. Sure, don't need a sound effect, just do a red flash on the boarder. Oh wait, that's not done either. So often you may not een know you've been hit. Overall, I get what the combat was going for, but it still needs help.
The audio is sub-par. While the music is decent, the sound effects themselves are in serious need of help. Many of the effects are really low and are easily drowned out by the music, forcing you to turn the music down and your computer's volume up to hear anything. Even then, the sound effects themselves aren't exactly excellent quality.

To be honest, this kinda feels like something I'd find on Newgrounds in terms of quality. Sad thing is I've played better games on Newgrounds. In its current state, I can't recommend it at all.

reviewText:
This game is pretty damn awesome.

If you like metal, gothic pixel art and frustratingly hard bullsh*t like old Castlevania or Ghosts'n'Goblins, this is a game for you. The soundtrack, the aesthetics, the atmosphere...it's all close to perfect. I'd actually say this is a spiritual successor to the NES metal tribute game Holy Diver, which is a similar level of badassery but was sadly limited by the possibilities of the NES.

Now, I'd only have one criticism of this game - which is a big one though: it needs customisable controls.
The keyboard controls just don't feel intuitive to me (and I realise this was designed for a gamepad, but I'm just more used to playing on keyboard). At the very least, there should be a menu option to show a basic explanation of the controls, I've died a bunch of times before I actually figured out how to do the super move.

I've also seen a lot of people complain that the controls are slow and unresponsive, but I personally think that's an artistic choice. This game is supposed to be a tribute to old games like Castlevania and Ghosts'n'Goblins, and those also have similarly slow controls - I have such fond childhood memories of raging over the sluggish controls in The Castlevania Adventure on gameboy, I'm used to this by now. It's not intolerably slow, so it passes imo.

I'd recommend this because the developer said they'd fix the controls, so I'll hope that my problems with the game will be gone in the future. If they are, this gets a full 10/10 from me.

reviewText:
Slain now what an outrageously brilliant name for a game follows in the same footsteps as gaming classics such as Castlevania & Rastan etc so if you remember those then you are sure to want to play this game.

First thing you will notice about Slain is the gorgeous pixel art graphics and amazing metal soundtrack, animation is also pretty darn good but do bear in mind that it's keeping with traditions so may appear to the perfectionists out there to be missing a few frames but it works well and as intended.

Difficulty is something i'm delighted to see in this game, it pays homage in a really good way to classic platformers of the past in that it's a very challenging without being insanely difficult that it wouldn't overly frustrate you so that's all good. Pixel perfect is a good way to describe the collision detection in this game, that is to say how close to an object you have to be before impact occurs, this is somewhat important so i would describe it as being tight in this regard so do be careful and time your jumps to perfection.

Controls are spot on, for reference i am playing with keyboard which uses cursor keys for control of your character and other keys for slash etc. This isn't a control system that gets used these days but something you would have seen years ago but for me this just feels very natural, didn't try gamepad controls but it's there for those who prefer it and also i didn't have any control issue's and any kind of input lag either. I will just say that keyboard bindings are not listed in the launcher/configuration and there is virtually no options ingame apart from music and sound fx volume.

I won't spoil what the rest of the game has to offer as that should be for you to discover but there are some great little features and surprises in store.

Plus points

Metal soundtrack
Pixel art graphics (amazing really)
Slick controls
Great difficulty

Negative points

Lack of options
Some achievements are currently bugged

Just to sum up would i recommend this game? Yes i certainly do especially if you love and remember classic action platformers but do bear in mind that it's a challenging game too so if that's your thing then you could do a lot worse than giving Slain a shot and i rate it 8.9/10.

For reference i purchased this game myself and didn't receive a free key from the developer or publisher and in no way related to them, thanks for reading and hope that you all enjoy your experience.

reviewText:
Pretty cool game

Things I like:
- Graphics are metal - I really love the look of this game.  The art for the environment and enemies is all top-notch imo.  At times the grunginess of it all can make traps, etc hard to see, but overall - beautifully done!
- OST is metal and adds a lot to the experience (albeit a bit repetitive in the guitar riff dept)  There are times where I feel the music is marred by the distortion.  Mainly because I'm not a fan of the tone - it's a bit dry and high on treble.  It overpowers the rest of the music.  Just my opinion, either way, well done and it certainly fits!
- I love the overall theme.  Feels like it was ripped from a death or black metal album.

Things IMO that could improve with patching, etc:
- SFX are weak!  This game could really use some decent SFX - they're not terrible atm, but I would've loved to have just stopped in the middle of a level and bask in the ambience of evil winds blowing through the trees, far-off screaming, or when you hit something, you really hear it, which brings me to the next point...
- JUICE.  For a game where everything is in your face, when I hit or kill something, I want to FEEL it.  A little screenshake and more meaty SFX for hits and kills would go a long way in improving the experience.
- Enemies either get knocked back or stay put and chop when you hit them.  I don't see any consistant pattern, so it's a bit difficult to be strategic with some encounters.  Hit timing, knock-back, etc could be tightened up some more.

Overall, at this time, I would recommend it to fans of sidecsrolling action games who are looking to scratch that nolstalgia itch with something new.  I hope the developers take some of the player feedback and implement any suggestions they find worthy.  If they do, then the game would be definitely be better for it!

reviewText:
So I've read alot of reviews talking about bad controls, no mapping, all kinds of problems with SFX, etc. Also talking about bad AI, lack of explanation, and more.

Honestly, I was ready for the worst when I started playing. Expecting to find a game full of great visuals and music but not much else. I was very very wrong. I don't know what people are playing on, if they are playing earlier builds, etc. But I had no problem playing this game and think it is a fantastic ride.

Let me first say, if you are playing this on keyboard, I have no advice. Please buy a gamepad as that is obviously how its intended to be played. I tried this on both a wired 360 controller as well as an NES USB controller and both worked great. If you were a fan of the NES Castlevania games, then you will immediately understand this game. None, and I mean, NONE of the controls are a problem. They are just the like the whip in Castlevania, there is a slight delay between the button press and the execution of the swing, you need to use strategy. This is not Cave Story or Dishwasher Samurai. The combat is not combo driven or twitchy. This is about taking time, learning, and dying alot. This is old school.

I have never written a review for a game on Steam. I just had to chime in when I saw the plethora of negative reviews and felt they were either being unfair or expecting something from the game that I wasn't.

Some people want more explained in the controls/tutorial. I, for one, applaud the lack of it. Remember experimenting with different buttons and attacks to figure things out? That's what you do here. By the end of the first stage, I had learned everything...and I believe that was the original intent.

So in conclusion, I don't want to say other people are wrong. They bought the game and are entitled to their opinion. But I just wanted to supply another point of view. This game is fantastic and I really can't wait to die alot more in the coming levels. OH, also never had a pause or quitting problem...pressing start on the controller, then exit...worked fine for me...

reviewText: I honestly do not understand all the negative reviews here.   I purchased Slain expecting a (Gorgeous) sluggish sloppy mess that was going to be hopefully patched in the near term to address the major shortcomings in the gameplay.  I have been following this game for a long time, and the dev's seem to be very engaged and genuinely desire to provide the best product they can, so I decided what the hell - I'll give em the chance.  It sounds like perhaps there are some optimization issues that at the time of me writing this need to be resolved for some folks, but the devs are already looking into it.  Anyhow, I saw none of this.  Instead of a 12 buck gamble on a future quality product though, I was pleased to discover a very enjoyable game right out of the box!  I'm running on a i7, 16 gb ram with 2x 770gtx cards, and Im using an xbox 360 controller like a filthy console peasant would.  I have not tried with a keyboard but with that said, I have played the game on max graphics quality and it handled exactly like I hoped it would.  Volgar the Viking or old school early Castlevania games would be the best approximation of gameplay that I can think of.  Perhaps the old Blackthorne game from Blizzard?  These are all good things - they were all fun games!  The controls are simple, and the combo chaining crowd will likely be confused by the fairly straight forward approach, but that's the point - this is an homage to the classic 16 bit side scroller, and they were all about making the most of pretty basic gameplay.  The game is challenging, but the ballance is well done - some fights are intended to beat you to a pulp but if you play smart you will live through it  there is always a health pickup to keep you going.  The pace is good, and if you keep your cool, you will do just fine.   This game is dripping with atmosphere.  The graphics are absolutely stunning - some of the finest pixel art I have ever seen, channeling the very best of the 16 bit consol era along with the glory or the old VGA pentium days of platform gaming.  Every screencap is art.  The atmosphere is augmented by fantastic music and flavor narrative that complete the dark, Gothic environment and works on the same vibes that made Diablo or Symphony of the Night so engrossing.    This game by my observation is damned good.  It does what its supposed to do, and it does it well.  I don't understand where the negative posts came from, though they may well have valid points - what works on one computer may not work on another.  That said, from my own experience, this was exactly what I wanted.

reviewText: Slain! looks like a heavy metal Symphony of the Night or Super Castlevania IV but it plays more like the original trilogy of Castlevania games for the NES. It's difficult, the controls are stiff and require precision & timing, and there's little in the way of explaining the game's mechanics. All of this seems to have been by design. You're definitely going to want to play this with a gamepad. If you're an oldschool Castlevania veteran you should feel right at home here but if you're expecting a more forgiving action-platformer or a Metroidvania you'll find yourself initially frustrated and possibly disappointed. There are some rough edges here in terms of presentation: sound effects v background music, minor performance issues, occassional crashes. These will likely get smoothed out in time. As mentioned by everyone, the aesthetic of the game is fantastic with great attention to detail. It's more Castlevania than Castlevania with gothic horror on display everywhere. The soundtrack is excellent and totally appropriate. Bottom line: if you love the original Castlevania or Castlevania 3 or if you're a fan of classic hard arcade-y NES titles (e.g., Ninja Gaiden) you should grab this. If you're more interested in exploration over platform puzzles this isn't really for you. If you're expecting inventory management & leveling up over tough action requiring persistence and precision then maybe this isn't the title for you.

reviewText:
A better review of the game. (This might be a tad bit arrogent)

So I like this game and here is why:
1. I like the difficulty with the game
2. I like the old school feel to it
3. There is a learning curve to the game and it rewards you for learning

So lets delve into this:
A. Graphics
B. Game Play
C. Music
D. Controls

Graphics:
Excellent graphics. It brings back memories of Ghost and Gobblins and the 8 bit era. Very metal, very metal. The only complaint is that some of the traps blend in very easily into the environment, although that may be the intent of the developers.

Game Play:
You have access to quite a few things that make the game interesting. To discover them is part of the game, and the game was meant to relive some of the old style hype. So if you discover the flame sword fairly early on and then die, then can you re-equip it? or is it gone forever? (HINT: LOOK AT THE CONTROL SECTION). You have access to three primary attacks with one screen wipe: Regular slash, beheading slash, range magic attack, and magic bomb. With the other two unlock weapons or so, you get different effects with each of the slashes. For example, the flame sword is faster and moves you further across the screen, while the ice axe will throw enemies quite a distance from you.
There is an indicator for everything, but you would have to figure out what it means, and I will make a beginners guide on what each one means. For example, why do enemies have a red line around their necks? or why is there blood all over that patch of ground that the surrounding area lacks?
Each enemy has a clear pattern and a clear counter play to them and some have counter play to alternative attacks. (HINT: DO NOT BOMB THE BIG RED SKELETONS) so the frustation there is that the patterns will change as you unlock more weapons. But I like a game that evolves with you.

Music:
I like the chords that are playing in the background. Yeah the repeat every so often, and so times they cover up sound clues to what you need to do next. Aside from that, you can control the music from the pause menu. If you don't like metal chords, then play with no sound.

Controls:
This seems to be the biggest complaint of the game. However, I disagree with those complaints. Before the game loads, a white box shows up and you can change the controls from there. The controls are as follows for those that do not have a joy stick or game pad:
arrow keys for move left, move right, jump and block (which is down)
Q for quick slash
W for beheading slash
1 for range magic attack
2 for normal sword
3 for flame sword
4 for ice axe
p for pause
enter for continue or navigating the menu's
Now for some of that good old explaination for how the controls work:
Your momentum is controlled by a few things: how long you are holding the key, and whether or not you have taken damage. Damage stops your momentum, so a couple of parts are hard because of a range enemy on the other side of a pit. That was fun to figure out.
The platforms that are solid are solid through and through. That means if you try to jump to another platform from underneath, you will bonk your head and lose some of your momentum.
Each weapon has a plus and a minus to how it works:
Normal weapon is a basic no bonus and no minus tool. The downside is that other weapons will handle situations better and you will take damage from enemies, because this things has a very small stun lock.
Range magic is good for dealing with weak enemies that you are having some trouble reaching. It consumes a small amount of mana, but with a full bar you can maybe fire it off about 10 times.
Flame sword is good agains witches. It is faster and deals less damage, while moving you farther with each attack.
Ice axe is good against most creatures, but terrible against witches. Each swing has a big stun time and the final swing in a normal combo knocks an enemy back far enough for you to reset and move.

TLDR:
The game's difficulty comes from not giving you any sort of tutorial to learn anything. It expects you to 1. be patient and not click, click through the game. 2. pay attention and try different combo's to advance. 3. finally focus on how each enemy fights. This game is a departure from the normal here is the first level, now we will walk you through the tutorial before letting you go HAM. Be patient and you will eventually make it through.

reviewText:
First Impressions after playing for an hour. This only reflects the first level of the game:

The game's combat is kinda....crap. Against weak enemies you can just mash the attack button and stun lock them into oblivion. For tougher enemies with more health, you can either spam your magic attach (which is rightly limited to avoid abuse) or trap them on a ledge to easily beat them without risking health (enemies can't jump and will only attack if you're right next to them).

I'd normally feel bad about that, but the combat just feels so slow. Trying to mash against a boss just starts a slap fight you're doomed to lose, so this is one where you must master the art of the jump slash - which is much faster and allows you to keep moving.

There is a backdash function which appears to exist to make combat more deliberate and complex, but enemies' attacks always seem to begin before your attack animation ends, so you're better off with the jump slash. (Maybe allow the backdash to cancel current attacks to make dodging more fluid?)

The music is ....fine. Honestly, metal can be cool, but, stretched over long periods with no vocals and incessant repetition, I, personally, couldn't stand it. After truning off the music, the game took a different tone. Instead of listening to thrashing power chords, I heard the dripping of blood and...not much else. The sound design relies pretty heavily on the idea that everything will just be drowned out by the music so not much actually has a sound effect.

The biggest complaint I have with the game, though, is the platforming. I did not think going in that this game would have such a strong platofmer component to it. Certainly, I figured I would run and jump to various challenges, but the first level basically plays out like:

Mash to kill an enemy,
jump over moving platorms moving up and down
jump over insta-kill trap
jump over moving platorms moving up and down
mash to kill an enemy
jump over moving platforms moving up and down
jump over insta-kill trap
jump over moving platforms moving up and down


To put it bluntly, the level design for the first level is somewhat tedious with a lot traps and pits that will kill you instantly - forcing you to restart from your last checkpoint, and, with such slow, limited movement, it doesn't feel engaging, or satisfying, to keep jump slashing my way through ghosts just to get across the same set of 4 moving platforms I know I've seen at least 3 times before.


I like this game - I like action adventure games with fast combat and striking visuals - this game....tries at that.
I'll keep my copy and continue playing to see how it goes (toggling the music as I go to give it a listen), but, so far, its in dire need of polish.

At first, I did recommend this title. I have to take back my review, and rewrite it without nostalgia glassess on, as this game is not what it appears to be. It's awful.

I will commit to saying this game is brutal. The art itself is very well done, however the story is atrocious as it is compiled by terrible writing, not including typos, for example “there are definately wolves in this forest.”

It gets worse, as even some bosses with use drivel that you would see in a teenager’s text messages “WTF”.

Moving beyond the terrible writing, the combat becomes repetitive, and because of the extreme difficulty level the game sets as a standard, the slow-swinging hero Bathoryn has a hard time of dispatching enemies.

Even after being able to shapeshift into a wolf, the game is so unforgiving that at times it almost seems capricious with enemy locations and traps instant killing you.

Checkpoints are somewhat frequent but that does not make up for this half-♥♥♥♥♥ mess that takes inspiration from Castlevania Symphony of the Night and Rondo of Blood.

The protagonist isn’t as fast as you would expect from Alucard, nor is he nearly as quick with his attacks. I understand the developer wanted this heavy metal theme for the game, but the keyboard mapping is questionable at best. There is even a dedicated keystroke for decapitating enemies… which only regenerates mana.

You start the game waking up in a tomb, and there is no tutorial.

This game has so much potential, it is squandered on poor development. If the developers invested more time, they could have implemented RPG elements, and a bigger weapon variety, maybe even armor.

Avoid this game like the plague, and just enjoy the art that you can do a simple search for. Otherwise, after having played this game for longer than I would have liked, I wish I had a physical copy to destroy while listening to Behemoth and send it to the developer.

This game is shameful to even compare to SOTN, or Rondo of Blood (both of which are both better choices than this joke).
